description: It's not very smart about picking up on cover art, but as a music player, it does in fact play music.
Simplicity in its perfection. I choose this over analogs due to native Gnome UI integration.
it does not show in default applications
GNOME Music is OK. But it doesn't have a lot of features that the other music players have. Of course, it does play music, but more features wouldn't hurt.
Hope, Gnome music development team will add some features.

I love GNOME's aesthetic and the simplicity of their apps, but a music library manager needs to be way way more. MTP support is desperately needed. The UI is so gross. The old iTunes UI of Rhythmbox looks sooo much better.

Rhythmbox had everything and on Fedora it barely works anymore. I love the GNOME ecosystem, but I don't see this program going anywhere. You had a great program in Rhythmbox, I don't see why it needed to be replaced by something this limited and unfriendly to the user.

To start off, GNOME Music looks good. Songs are laid out in a neat, organized way, with 4 different views and a search bar. Animations and UX are smooth and consistent.

The actual player experience? That's rough. Music plays well, but there are quirks. I've found that after an extended amount of time playing, Music will suddenly crash, stopping playback of my songs.

Next, finding Music. Unlike other players, Music seems to require perfect tags to organize songs, artists and albums. I have found that some songs do not show up in their proper album or under an artist, and at the top of the Songs view I find a lot of "Untitled - 0:00 - Unknown Artist - Untitled". The songs play, and sometimes they are the missing songs, while other times they are duplicates of songs already found, where no duplicates exist in my Music folder.

Overall, GNOME Music has potential to be great, but for now I recommend Lollypop if you are looking for a good player with GNOME integration.

System: Arch Linux, GNOME Music 3.28.0
Esy to use and blends well
There are no features that make the app useful. You'd be better off just using the file manager or a different music app.
Nice clean UI, but, too many bugs to count. Progress bar missing, cannot skip through the song's timeline, playlists don't display songs added until the app is closed and reopened...
summary: Simple and clean UI, too many bugs

description: It's a weird app. On the one hand it has a nice UI, but on the other hand it lacks basic functions like playlist.
I have all my music on a second HDD. But the program only plays music files in ~/Music and there doesn't seem to be a way to change/add a new directory.
works for me well. nothing seems to be issues.

It use more than 2gb of ram and one core is stuck at 100% on an intel i7 haswell.
For playing music that is simply not convenient. the ux is nice though, looks like an android app in a good way
summary: nice ux but more powerhungry than chrome

description: It's much easier and cleaner than Rhythmbox!

I think GNOME Music is a good addition to the default apps and it feels great. It has all the basic tools you need to play your songs/albums and search for music. Although it lacks advanced features, it should be more than enough for your playback needs.

One big drawback in my opinion, similar to GNOME Photos/Documents and other "basic management" apps of this desktop environment is that it is bound to the "tracker disk indexer" software.

You can't simply use it without your whole computer being indexed nor simply select or add music library folders it should read from.

I have read through some of the arguments but I couldn't find anyone that even technically convinced me why it is a hard dependency. In the end, all these nice basic apps are a "uninstall first" alongside tracker on new installations for me...

If you don't mind the indexing and limitations, then it's probably a 4 star app.
summary: Good UI & Player but depends on tracker disk indexer

description:
This will only look to the main 'Music' folder. 
Very restrictive if you choose to customise your file system.
Seems to be the only player that has this type of restriction
summary: Will not support Customised File Systems

description:
But I would really like to see 1 function:
Please let me open Files directly from Nautilus in GNOME Music!

GNOME Music does its job. It plays music, has an easy search, and your music library is presented in a decent UI.

However, the initial load does not give enough information about music files being indexed. GNOME Music relies on Tracker so if your music is already indexed it loads instantly, otherwise it can take some time. It also expects to find music in the ~/Music folder, or more specifically the directory set for XDG_MUSIC_DIR. You can override this by updating the XDG_MUSIC_DIR variable with your real music directory (eg. if it was on another HDD):

xdg-user-dirs-update --set MUSIC /path/to/music

Also, I find that with GNOME Music being written in Python means you can hit edges case that that the application doesn't know what to do and can just crash. It also consumes slightly more CPU/RAM than a lower-level language like C.

Decent but needs some polish.

Fits with the Gnome environment perfectly but the only feature that's really any good is the search.

You can't play a whole album just by clicking it. You can't "favourite" a track while it's playing or even from all views - you have to search for it and find it in a particular view. There's no play queue. There's no quick way to add a song to a Playlist - you have to click a button to then be able to select tracks and then click another button to add to a Playlist. A lot of album artwork doesn't load even when it does in other apps. It's often slow to load track lists when selecting an album. And it sometimes crashes.

Sorry, it's just not there yet.
summary: The look is spot on, but there's no functionality

The player is ok but at the end of the Lollypop is a far superior music player for gnome in every account. I highly recommend you try it

description: If you want to play in it first download songs.Youtube is better.

I sync my music from a cloud file service, so the fact that it only allows you to use ~/Music is silly, but at least it works with a symlink.

When I first installed it ~/Music was a folder. I opened Music, realized there was no way for it to use another folder, and then deleted ~/Music and replaced with a symlink. It populated songs correctly, but then would crash any time I tried to play a song. I wound up uninstalling and reinstalling, with the symlinked directory already in place, and that seems to have fixed it.

I appreciate that it handles album artists correctly (grouping albums by album artist if present, followed by artist as a fallback), because this is essential for a substantial number of my albums. The album art view in the Albums and Artists views is nice, and those views are pretty usable.

The fact that the Songs view doesn't have a header and as far as I can tell doesn't allow sorting by anything other than song title is really bad. I have >3000 songs, so this entire view is pretty much useless. I would complain that there are no settings that allow you to update what columns are shown here, but since you can't sort anyway, I guess it doesn't matter?

The general lack of any configurability is not great. The provided defaults are mostly okay (except for the Songs view, as mentioned above), but it would be nice to be able to adjust keyboard shortcuts, displayed track information, etc.

All that being said, it's probably the cleanest music player I've used yet for Ubuntu, with the sanest deafults.

quite possibly the worst excuse for a branded software product.
* you need your data in tracker.
* network files in tracker are unreliable.
* the database doesn't update well, fast, easily or at all most of the time

Needs some serious updates I think. (The one star is too much credit!)

description: The app WILL work, it'll search all the defalut locations for music. The app also fails to see all my music on my NAS despite adding it to the searched locations in the system settings for files. If the only music you have is located in your music folder and have no other audio files on your PC it'll be fine, if you differ from that even slightly go with something else. Also once you install this on Ubuntu 22.04 it can't be removed which sucks.

description: I had the metadata for all of my music files perfectly set up in Rhythmbox, so I decided to give GNOME Music another try because it is more aesthetically pleasing. Unfortunately, it got the album artwork all mixed up even though the album artwork displayed perfectly in Rhythmbox. It also displayed the names of some of the albums twice. Additionally, when I clicked on the name of the song I wanted to play when a song is already playing, it would pause instead of switching to the new song.

This is what I would come out with if I were to write a music player just for myself – but it's actually meant for the general public, so it's not nearly good enough. Not quite feature-rich, all it can do is fetch audio files from your ~/Music directory and load cover art. You can make a symbolic link from your external hard drive if you need it, though. GNOME is really overdoing their simplicity philosophy, making their final products like Music or Fragments basically useless.

If you are not having any app, that can play music, you may want to have a look at gnome music. If you can choose, there are plenty of options, that can be set as default music program and that can be used for larger libraries. Lollypop and rhythmbox are better alternatives and even the elementary music delivers a better UX.

It's like gnome shooting in it's own leg :( if newcomers try this app it will most likely discourage them from using the whole desktop environment. Terrible usage of whitespace, excessive padding on all tabs, impossible to use in a small window as texts get truncated and unreadable while padding around elements remains huge. Slow, no configuration.

description: GNOME Music has a nicht interface, but when you can't even select an additional music folder (apart from the XDG standard folder), its usefulness is quite limited. It isn't a real music player, also it has no functionality to connect to UPNP or Bonjour sources, Jamendo or other remote sources. I suppose that when it was originally written, the expectation had been that the functionality would eventually be expanded, but development has been dormant for years and years now. I don't think anyone really uses it.
